[2022-04-14T17:14:44] Lechu: throttle limit, set with potentiometer
[2022-04-14T17:16:04] Happy Giraffe: True: Power limit mode Hold both the left brake handle and the throttle handle bar, then power on the system, the adapter will toggle the power limited/unlimited mode, after the switching, the buzzer will ring three times to indicate the mode change, release the throttle and left brake. The principle of Power limit mode is to scale the throttle handle bar's input to the L level, ignores the H, M, L state. So set the L level to meet your local regulations. When power on, the buzzer will ring to prompt the power limit mode state: Ring one time ---- Limited mode. Ring three times ---- Unlimited mode.

[2022-04-15T02:08:24] Artem Bulashev: So
[2022-04-15T02:08:49] Artem Bulashev: 48a at 75v = battery limit 3600w per esc
[2022-04-15T02:08:51] Artem Bulashev: Vs
[2022-04-15T02:09:20] Artem Bulashev: 60a at 60v = 3600w per esc
[2022-04-15T02:10:21] Artem Bulashev: So at 20s you will only need 48a battery limit to actually get same performance (same battery limit)

[2022-04-19T00:06:05] Artem Bulashev: Li ion generally speaking should not be charged too fast
[2022-04-19T00:06:22] Artem Bulashev: Degradation from fast charging is a lot higher than from discharging
[2022-04-19T00:08:14] Artem Bulashev: So 1C is about max reasonable regeneration (short term). As for charger (long term) use lowest amps your time allows - FAST charger I would consider 0.33C = 3h empty to full (like when you forgot you will have to go in a few hours and scooter is not charged enough) 0.5C = 2h empty to full /extreme case like charging in restaurant during lunch stop
[2022-04-19T00:14:15] Happy Giraffe: Afterall charging makes a hefty chemical reactionüò≥

[2022-04-19T19:25:00] Unknown: 24F ‚ù§Ô∏è I run dual Nucular 12F 150a batt/250a phase max per motor/controller. [2022-04-23T15:12:42] Unknown: Guys, is there any major reason we don't use Lipo packs in parallel/series for our scooters? Was looking at some 12,000mah 6s packs and realized that a monsterrr battery could be made from a handful of them. 3 in series is 18s and 3 in parallel is 36ah with huge huge discharge and charge rates. Would be a matter of mounting/securing them in the deck properly and then using either connectors (probably a lot of connectors) or soldering them together to make the series and parallel connections. Has anyone ever done or tried this? Just curious

[2022-04-24T15:13:53] Unknown: If you look back at my posts on here, I would say less than half of them are regarding Nucular. As Artem said, I think it's healthy to give other perspective. I'm never of mindset that one is better or anything like that. We talk about about a lot of helpful and useful things here other than VESC, which I have been a part of. I would like to think I bring something a little different to the table, a different perspective with different ideas and setup. It's never ever about bashing VESC, I think most people here know that. As a matter of fact, I've used VESC in many other applications than scooters and I think the firmware is absolutely brilliant. The issue we are dealing with right now is the available hardware that is limited for high output motors and batteries, which is why Paolo is building a custom high power VESC. I think that will be an amazing addition to the community. So again, just because I don't currently use VESC doesn't mean my contributions to the group are null and void. I remember the day perfectly when I shared the Nuc uLight module and everyone was like "what is that"... I explained it and Artem shared it with you, which maybe (not saying for sure) it gave you inspiration to create your light board. Ideas and other perspectives are healthy in our hobby. Roscheeee was rude and uncontrolled, literally attacking me which is why I had enough. Artem, thank you. And thank you all for everything you contribute. I learn more here than anywhere else honestly

[2022-04-24T23:44:06] Artem Bulashev: This web app can‚Äôt do any advance layout. It is only good to guesstimate. It is not precise enough unfortunately and is not able to calculate if flat layers would feel space better. Also doesn‚Äôt account for hight. So it is good for basic but sometimes you may gain by shifting cells away to reduce hight in expense of length , and it can‚Äôt do that either unfortunately (not sure why)

[2022-04-25T00:17:22] Unknown: You can't do stacked layout for example (cells laying horizontally in multiple levels where nickel/copper is folded)
[2022-04-25T00:22:54] Unknown: @artBula once you designed a d showed me my 20s9p layout,, I put it into that program and was able to replicate it but probably wouldn't have been able to come up with it own my using just that program, definitely couldn't get such exact measurements. There have been some e-bike guys on endless sphere that use that program to get an idea because it has the triangle layout for ebike frames... To get a general idea since it's really easy to use and get in the ballpark. From there you can take that info and put it into a cad program potentially saving a lot of time by having a general idea before you start

[2022-04-25T18:23:44] Unknown: Also BMS protects charge cycle and balances cells. A fuse cannot balance your cells. BMS for sure, ideally with discharge protection and charge protection. I personally prefer active balancer BMS such as JK but generally any smart BMS will do the job, keep you safe and keep your cells happy and balanced

[2022-04-25T18:53:05] Unknown: LoL. I would only use a dumb BMS if smart BMS wouldn't fit due to available space. Being able to see and monitor the cells with smart BMS is just too good of a feature to pass up. My JK BMS with active balancer is nice because you can toggle balance mode on/off at any state of charge, not just near full charge while charging. My battery hasn't needed to be balanced in the 320 miles I've used it for so far, so it's not "force balancing" at the top of the charge cycle. I also like to keep the balance function off during charge (and discharge) to get an accurate idea of how the cells are acting without the balancer making up for any inconsistencies.

[2022-04-26T21:07:10] Unknown: Yup, 6mm xt150 bullets is what I use for my Vsett 10 motor phase connectors üëå. Just make sure the phase wire itself is touching one side of bullet. If centered only solder will be the conductor from wire thru bullet and solder is shit for conducting. I flattened the phase wire around the inside diameter of the bullet and then soldered to get most wire to bullet direct contact as possible. Problem is, 6mm bullet solder area is much larger diameter than 11-12awg phase wires... So if centered it just sort of floats in the center with solder being the only connection

[2022-04-30T16:08:11] Unknown: Usually you want to put the ferrofluid in the air gap while the stator is in place. Putting in the fluid first, when the stator snaps back into the hub, the fluid tends to splash out a bit since the stator usually gets sucked in super hard due to magnets. I don't have a fancy machine to ease the stator in the hub, so mine anyways gets sucked in like a banshee. Does anyone have a different method? LoL

I didn't end up using the julets because I didn't like the quality of the housings (very soft and pliable plastic) and the wires were very brittle when I tried crimping them to JST pins. I bought all of my genuine Higo's from Kart... Along with my throttles

[2022-04-30T19:34:38] Unknown: I also dissected a Higo L1019 connector lol. The 2.5mm solid bullets just aren't made to handle high currents. Artem also made a good point that they're solid bullets with no spring action, so male to female fitment isn't as tight as a typical bullet connector that has a split spring action on the male
[2022-04-30T19:35:42] Unknown: Nice thing about the Higo l1019 is the phase wires are 11awg (stock Vsett is 12awg) and there are 7 signals wires, so plenty for halls and temp sensor, all bundled into 1 single wire. Great wire but limited power with the actual connectors
[2022-04-30T19:37:22] Unknown: I think pulling 220 phase amps and 80 battery amps on my rear motor alone (135/75 for front) would have been a little much for the 2.5mm solid bullets LoL

[2022-04-30T23:22:38] Unknown: NAMI uses the Higo L1019 wire and connectors? I didn't know that. Beautiful connectors and super clean but think about it, 2.5mm bullets. @artBula I'm sure you have some info on how many amps a 2.5mm bullet is capable of handling, even on AC current
[2022-04-30T23:23:59] Unknown: Again, the wire is beefy but I have doubts about the connector itself handling 150+ phase amps without heating up or creating a large resistance in the flow of current
[2022-04-30T23:24:45] Unknown: <photos/photo_3981@30-04-2022_23-24-45.jpg>
[2022-04-30T23:27:27] Unknown: 2mm bullet connectors = 20a Higo L1019 spec sheet says 45a... I have run mine on 60a battery and around 160a phase (per motor/connector) and it wasn't hot but... There is definitely some sort of resistance/bottlenecking happening even at those currents. I've been running even higher than that lately, so I'm glad I switched them out

[2022-05-03T19:53:33] Unknown: Of course. Auto angle detection and auto phase/hall orientation detection. Just like VESC does. I was thinking more along the lines of hardware/software quality comments LoL. Those guys basically did what Suc√© and Paolo are doing... They created their own hardware but took it a step further and created their own software as well. Then they made it available to the public in small limited batches with high quality control. He was a guy with an idea and ended up creating a system of products that turned out to be extremely robust, user friendly and capable. Then they also decided to start a telegram chat with live 24/7 support.
[2022-05-03T19:55:17] Paolo ‚Å≠: I think they do these little batch because same as me I have fear that Chinese company copy you pcb and sell .
[2022-05-03T19:56:41] Unknown: I think many people think they this big business with a factory. It's quite the opposite. It would be like Paolo making his own VESC and then branching out to start making them in larger batches available to the public. If He ends up creating a very successful design and finds supplier to make that design affordable, he now has a full time job as controller manufacturer out of his home, hires a software engineer and only makes quality products.
[2022-05-03T20:09:39] Unknown: Definitely one reason I'm sure. They also build them by hand to keep quality control tight. They offer 2 year warranty on non-potted and 3 year on potted controllers. Not sure if any other company out there has a controller built that robust to offer that sort of thing. I have been a member of their endless sphere chat and telegram chat for about 9 months and I have literally never heard of one failure just because and there are thousands of units in daily use, maybe ten thousand plus. There have been some firmware bugs here n there but those are usually corrected with a patch in short order. What I can say is, they (he, just a guy... like John at spintend) started out just like Paolo. A guy who wanted a controller better than what's currently out there. He turned that idea into a very successful business with a very successful line of products and firmwares to match, which is not an easy thing to do at all. And then you have no-brainers bashing them lol. They have accomplished what very few can in this niche hobby of ours.

[2022-05-07T14:31:38] Unknown: Basically F180 is identical to R160 So confusing

[2022-05-12T15:43:10] Mirono escooters: Yea flux are details
[2022-05-12T15:47:40] Happy Giraffe: If you burn all flux away it introduces some issues as it protects the joint but should be ok in this case
[2022-05-12T15:49:15] Mirono escooters: How does it protect?
[2022-05-12T15:51:19] Happy Giraffe: Flux is a chemical cleaning agent used before and during the soldering process of electronic components onto circuit boards. Flux is used in both manual hand soldering as well as the different automated processes used by PCB contract manufacturers. The main purpose of the flux is to prepare the metal surfaces for soldering by cleaning and removing any oxides and impurities. Oxides are formed when metal is exposed to air and may prevent the formation of good solder joints. The flux also protects the metal surfaces from re-oxidation during soldering and helps the soldering process by altering the surface tension of the molten solder.
[2022-05-12T15:51:49] Happy Giraffe: Basically keeps surfaces clean from oxide and shit
[2022-05-12T15:53:02] Mirono escooters: Sick
[2022-05-12T16:34:09] Happy Giraffe: https://www.gogobest.com/products/bezior-xf001-electric-moped-city-bike-old-fashion-power-assist-mountain-ebike?utm_campaign=affiliate&utm_content=p12990221615575123444&utm_medium=referral&utm_source=zbanx&utm_term=41977&variant=42549449064698&z_code=p12990221615575123444&z_pid=41977

[2022-05-17T22:19:40] Unknown: Yes of course. One of my 12Fs is potted and the other is not. My 6F is potted. My upcoming 24F will be potted. The potting compound also helps fets and cpu to run much cooler, vibration dampening and 100% waterproof. When buying new from Nucular, you choose potted or not potted. Potted has 3 year warranty and non potted has 2 year warranty

[2022-05-18T00:26:32] Unknown: Awesome. My experience with them has been really good. I run 140-150a battery max settings on my Nucs, so 9p is around 15-16a per cell. Battery temps never exceeded 30C so far and sag is really solid. Only really pull those 150a when I'm full throttle on open straightaway, so typical riding around I estimate is 40-120a most of the time
[2022-05-18T00:29:45] Happy Giraffe: I plan about 12A per cell, so if 7p then ~85A batt
[2022-05-18T00:56:01] Unknown: Super safe. I think it may be one of the highest capacity cells with most wh and lowest sag in the 12a continuous range. My batch was insanely matched. I didn't do any IR or capacity tests on them, just assembled the battery randomly. Set at .010v delta, my active balancer has yet to kick on in 83 days or so and well over 500 miles of use

[2022-05-21T03:52:22] Unknown: Proper potting compound is exactly like ferrofluid for motors. Creates contact between PCB and outer case/heatsink. My potted 12F on the rear runs cooler than my non potted 12F on the front and the rear controller works muchh harder (75/200 vs 65/130)
[2022-05-21T03:52:50] Artem Bulashev: And ubox fets layed with heatsink side to the PCB

[2022-05-21T04:54:31] Unknown: Controllers stay nice cool. Also have them sandwiches on plexiglass and 5mm thermal pad to keep vibrations down and further helps draw heat away. The 12Fs aren't working super hard so they only get a few C above ambient under hardest conditions lol
[2022-05-21T05:03:00] Unknown: I'd say about 90% of custom high power setups I've seen have controllers mounted externally in some fashion. Usually because the controllers are too large to fit inside deck, deck space is needed for high discharge/capacity battery and air cooling is the best for keeping temp down. Most of these high power setups aren't made to ride in the rain since the tires would lose traction anyways, so controllers outside isn't an issue. Even so, when mounted outside with wires facing down, the case keeps them well protected. Ubox has an odd port/wire design and case, so external placement would make mounting a challenge

[2022-05-24T21:40:39] Artem Bulashev: Here is full list :) Final design of Spin-Y throttle: - Scroll forword will work on normall controller like vsett / mini motors - Scroll back will have physical lock if you don‚Äôt want to scroll back, other wise Scroll back will activate E-brake at -20% position. Strength on e-brake is set by original display üòä‚úÖ - Cruise control button on the back! ‚ò∫Ô∏è works a lot better than original time based cruise inside Vsett / minimotor and other controllers üòú ‚Äî- It can also output signal so you can connect it to what you want, like horn - Modular buttons on top, will sell as an option. Dual 12mm - Total 6 wires from throttle. Short Manual I will write and incl as QR code - 0 band adjustment knob for one way throttle (for basic controllers) to remove dead zone completely (you move throttle scooter does it right away) ‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî extra info ‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî- - water protective coating üòç - micro computer (MCU) handles all the functions - 3.3v bi-directional output for smart controllers (vesc & others) - 5v one way throttle - dedicated e-brake wire that will close loop and make normal controllers engage ebrake üôÇ ‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî wires ‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî- 1. Power 5v 2. Ground 3. Bi-directional throttle (3.3v logic - smart controllers) 4. One way throttle (5v logic - normal controllers) 5. Brake line loop - (ebrake - normal controllers) 6. Cruise control button external signal ‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî on board adjustments‚Äî‚Äî- - knob to change start value for one way throttle (normal controller), this way you can adjust it to the band where you controller picks up throttle input without ‚Äúdeadband‚Äù right away as you move throttle.

[2022-05-29T02:09:03] Unknown: I asked on Vsett chat and didn't get a clear answer. Maybe someone here would have some additional input... Question for all the Magura/Aftermarket brake users. I know there have been struggles to get the brake line/banjo on the opposite side of the caliper (using the M6 bleed port for the new brake line location) and has caused some headaches finding the exact parts need. Then an M5 bleed port adapter is needed for bleeding. Since Vsett 10 (and zero 10x, 11x, Vsett 11, etc..) swingarms are symmetrical, is there a reason why the standard isn't to just flip flop the brakes to the opposite side? Rear right swingarm to front left and vice versa and then just install motor opposite direction, change tire and rotor direction and done. Has anyone done this? or does anyone have input on if this would work or present any issues?

[2022-05-30T20:08:36] Mirono escooters: How would you directly spotweld copper? No way?
[2022-05-30T20:11:59] Paolo ‚Å≠: No
[2022-05-30T20:14:12] Mirono escooters: I saw something with tungsten tips. Also no?
[2022-05-30T20:14:19] Mirono escooters: Ill stick with sandwich
[2022-05-30T20:18:30] Happy Giraffe: Goodluck getting baseplate flat against all mosfets with good, even pressureüòÇ
[2022-05-30T20:18:35] Paolo ‚Å≠: Not tips problem
[2022-05-30T20:19:10] Paolo ‚Å≠: Copper cant be fused with nickel, the welding is super fragile due to oxigen
[2022-05-30T20:19:25] Paolo ‚Å≠: If you have argon gas you can try
[2022-05-30T20:21:19] Unknown: Especially .2 copper. No way. Even with split
[2022-05-30T20:21:59] Unknown: Even if welder is strong enough, K-Weld with super caps say.. you'd be introducing a lot of heat to the cell. Especially on the negative can side
[2022-05-30T20:22:29] Unknown: Positive tab is floating so not as crucial, positive can take a lot more heat before it goes into the cell
[2022-05-30T20:23:18] Unknown: Copper probe tips direct to copper, especially .2, will stick (ruin your probes quickly) and the heat will disperse too fast to get a solid weld. I welded a handful of copper to copper welds on .1 and it was okay. Probes did stick a bit but also only using enough heat for .1
[2022-05-30T20:27:55] Mirono escooters: Okidoki , sad
[2022-05-30T20:28:01] Mirono escooters: Sandwich is da way
[2022-05-30T20:29:24] Unknown: Is. I mean, you can use that 2p copper... Just would be wise to also use nickel or plated steel tabs on top as a weld aid. Also, .2 copper is thick. I used .1 but also bought .15 to experiment with. .15 is definitely weldable but welds were super strong and consistent with .1
[2022-05-30T20:29:45] Mirono escooters: I will use 0.1 too
[2022-05-30T20:30:02] Unknown: Is equal to (actually better than) .4 nickel
[2022-05-30T20:30:13] Mirono escooters: Love copper,.with 0.3mm√ó6 nickel i would need so much for 60a

[2022-06-08T22:53:05] Unknown: If you bridge there only 2 cells are transferring the current from one P group to another
[2022-06-08T22:54:08] Paolo ‚Å≠: Only 16s?
[2022-06-08T22:54:10] Unknown: <photos/photo_4701@08-06-2022_22-54-10.jpg>
[2022-06-08T22:55:29] Unknown: The furthest cells will struggle to discharge evenly. Entire P group of current is bottlenecking at that 2 cell interconnect. 8p worth of current passing through 2 cells of connections
[2022-06-08T22:55:39] Mirono escooters: Better horizontal series layers
[2022-06-08T22:56:12] Mirono escooters: wonder why this design choice
[2022-06-08T22:56:29] Unknown: Like this... Horrible cell layout
[2022-06-08T22:56:58] sombre_enfant: This happen a lot on ebike but they less devil on amps than us
[2022-06-08T22:58:06] Mirono escooters: Ebike cell layout can be super tricky
[2022-06-08T22:58:29] Unknown: Usually yes... In any case having so little series connections is not good for heat, even discharge or resistance. Furthest cells can discharge slower and then the p groups equalize causing even more stress
[2022-06-08T22:58:39] Unknown: Ebike triangle layouts very tricky
[2022-06-08T22:58:41] Mirono escooters: I used 2 1awg cable to bridge series connection, because Otherwise id have a super long 1 cell series connection, haha
[2022-06-08T22:58:43] sombre_enfant: Thinking about layout blow my head up when its not common one
[2022-06-08T22:59:15] Unknown: Haha.. so true. Love rectangle scooter decks
[2022-06-08T22:59:56] Unknown: Yes, maybe even multiple bridges or a 2nd layer of plate to help distribute. More robust series connections the better
[2022-06-08T23:00:00] Mirono escooters: I forced myself to take breaks and think and sleep over it, i knew i would make mistakes otherwise
[2022-06-08T23:00:17] Mirono escooters: Used 2 layers on 2 points i doubted
[2022-06-08T23:00:36] Mirono escooters: Max delta v 0.03 60a, standstill 0.01, wich i find super good

[2022-06-09T00:57:22] Unknown: Can fold over the sides or fold back over on top of itself. Solder wires FIRST then spot weld to the cells. Don't solder wires after copper is welded to the cells since you don't want to introduce heat to them
[2022-06-09T00:58:18] Unknown: You want your main wires to cover as many of the cell tips as possible for even draw/discharge
[2022-06-09T00:58:56] Unknown: Same with the series connections wherever possible
[2022-06-09T00:59:05] Unknown: More coverage is best

[2022-06-11T03:36:24] rosheee: Does more heatpipes mean better cooling? As a general rule, more heatpipes means better cooling. Additional vapor chambers may aid in heat diffusion for some units, but are not as common as traditional heatpipes.
[2022-06-11T03:36:28] Unknown: Lemme try n find one example for you. I will actually waste my time looking because it is that good
[2022-06-11T03:36:38] rosheee: Are heat pipes good for cooling? Heat pipes are the best choice for cooling electronic devices, because depending on the length, the effective thermal conductivity of heat pipes can be up to several thousand times higher than that of a copper rod.
[2022-06-11T03:36:50] rosheee: apor chambers are most often used to spread heat to a local heat sink, whereas heat pipes are generally better for moving heat to a remote sink. Vapor chambers have a very large continuous area, allowing for better isothermalization of the heat sink.

[2022-06-12T04:26:20] rosheee: how connect heat sensor
[2022-06-12T04:26:26] rosheee: 1 of the 2 lines to -?
[2022-06-12T04:26:29] rosheee: and the other to temp
[2022-06-12T04:29:31] Unknown: Temp sensor... NTC 10k or 100k (100k good for VESC) B:3950 No polarity, wire order does not matter. Hook 1 wire to hall ground. Other to temp sensor wire to VESC
[2022-06-12T04:29:35] Unknown: Super simple
[2022-06-12T04:29:44] rosheee: i have one
[2022-06-12T04:29:48] rosheee: ah ok
[2022-06-12T04:29:52] rosheee: ground and temo
[2022-06-12T04:29:55] rosheee: temp
[2022-06-12T04:29:56] rosheee: thx
[2022-06-12T04:29:58] Unknown: Very easy. Hardest part is running the extra wire
[2022-06-12T04:30:30] Unknown: Use hall ground for one wire.... Other wire goes to VESC temp sensor input. That's it

[2022-06-13T15:33:43] Unknown: ASI BAC controllers are super powerful from what I know of them. I have heard they can be really tricky to setup and make setting adjustments. Not sure if the user is able to just go in and change settings. I feel like they come programmed for specific motors, which is strange. [2022-06-14T01:07:26] Artem Bulashev: Forge aluminum‚Ä¶ well sounds good and if it is so it should thab be strong enough in all points beside point 1. But I would reduce chance of failing there down to 50% instead of 100%. Geometry can be smart enough to compensate such structural location - location of it weakens construction SIGNIFICANTLY as whole is too close to lower edge, and there are 2 opposing forces at all times and bump introduces 3 vectorial force onto that joint. It has high but not absolute chance of collapsing at that spot if it is forged high quality aluminum.

[2022-06-14T15:56:31] Happy Giraffe: You don't want li-ion?üòÇ
[2022-06-14T15:57:16] Happy Giraffe: How much power/capacity does the lifepo give vs. Li-ion on same size? Assuming you use like Samsung 48x cells at 12A
[2022-06-14T16:12:36] Unknown: I looked briefly into the rabbit hole of using lipo's for our use. Main problems right off the rip were mounting/securing multiple single packs, wiring would probably be a mess and the toughest part I think is charging. Parallel groups can be charged together but if you're in the 16s-20s range, most Lipo chargers like iCharger Duo only go up to 6s and 7s, so would need to disconnect the series connections before each charge. Output would be superior to lithium cylindrical cells and capacity probably would as well. Lots of bike guys use pouch cells which can be high discharge (like 10c) , high charge (like 5c) and large capacity. EIG C020 pouch cells were supposedly amazing but I think EIG no longer makes them or is in business
[2022-06-14T16:13:56] Mirono escooters: You can just use a regular bms for lipo
[2022-06-14T16:14:32] Mirono escooters: Main problems are safety tho, especially mounting it And price
[2022-06-14T16:15:01] Unknown: But I think the charging process would still be an issue
[2022-06-14T16:15:07] Mirono escooters: Why
[2022-06-14T16:15:11] Mirono escooters: Li ion and lipo same process

[2022-06-16T03:31:38] Unknown: After using them if I thought they were shit, I wouldn't stand behind and I would have 4 of their controllers sitting in my house lol. I have a solid 600-650 miles (1000km or so) on my 12Fs. Honestly dual 12Fs are probably more than enough for 95% of scooters out there. The other 5% 70mm magnet monsters with 4awg phase wires can definitely benefit from dual 24Fs. They aren't limitless but they perform up to what the spec sheets say. A 24F is definitely not as capable as an ASI BAC8000 or fardriver 530. They aren't the most powerful in the world but they work great when you use them properly. 2 of my controllers (12F and 24F) came from a guy in Australia who used them for racing dirt bikes... In the Australia heat for 2-3 years. Now I'm using them and they work just as good as the day they were shipped new from Russia. There is definitely something to be said for that.
[2022-06-16T03:40:39] rosheee: Yah
[2022-06-16T03:40:53] rosheee: They are also idk how many x the size of what i use xD
[2022-06-16T03:40:58] Unknown: Only difference between 6,12,24 is the number of fets and power capabilities/limits and obviously total MOSFET IR due to the different number of fets in parallel. Design, hardware, software are all identical. Literally pick your power and they are all equally good. Cool thing is you can run a 12F in the front and 24F in the rear or 6 and 12 or whatever combo

[2022-06-16T11:57:14] koxx / Francois Deslandes: anyone has formula to calculate mean phase amps from 3 phases currents ?
[2022-06-16T11:58:07] koxx / Francois Deslandes: and mean phase voltage from 2 phase voltages ?
[2022-06-16T12:00:21] rosheee: Divide the power consumption in watts by the line voltage multiplied by the power factor to find the amperage. For three phase circuits the power factor is the square root of 3. If your calculator doesn‚Äôt have a square root function, use 1.73 as an approximation of the square root of 3. For example, a three phase circuit using 25,000 watts of power and a line voltage of 250 will have a current flow of 25,000/(250 x 1.73), which is equal to 57.80 amperes.
[2022-06-16T12:01:09] rosheee: the power is the sum of the phase voltages multiplied by the line current = 2 x Vphase x Iphase.

[2022-06-17T10:52:17] Artem Bulashev: A bit better than 48x and thus better than 50g
[2022-06-17T10:52:25] Artem Bulashev: At 5/10/15amps
[2022-06-17T10:54:25] Artem Bulashev: No
[2022-06-17T10:55:05] Artem Bulashev: That is PEI coated layer on it to increase adhesion. It is made special for hard to stick filaments like ABS and PC
[2022-06-17T10:55:19] Artem Bulashev: PETG is THE STICKIEST of all materials
[2022-06-17T10:57:45] Artem Bulashev: That is why it is often printed 0.1mm higher - to reduce adhesion, or printed on surface that doesn‚Äôt stick as much - glass, metal, non smooth PEI COATED SHEET, FR4 and others Smooth PEI is about THE STICKIEST surface you can find and you just can not print the stickiest filament on it (PETG) because they will fuse and come of together with PEI layer
[2022-06-17T10:59:36] Artem Bulashev: Def user error so no warranty case Glue stick is used to control stickiness - it helps to adhere and helps to separate, but I prefer not to use such solution. Just found good surface for PETG and another bed for abs and another for pla

[2022-06-17T19:49:03] rosheee: C3 is inside he told me
[2022-06-17T19:49:07] rosheee: The gap is more
[2022-06-17T19:51:48] rosheee: Why are your bearings C3? - Bearing King https://www.bearing-king.co.uk/article/why-are-your-bearings-c3
[2022-06-17T19:51:48] rosheee: Internal clearance being C3 means that the bearing has room for expansion if needed between the races of the bearing, whilst holding the outer ring and moving the inner ring in a radial movement you will detect a little amount of play between the two rings. All standard clearance bearings have this movement, it may only be a small amount of movement but is controlled by international standards. C3 means the bearing has more clearance than standard. For example we may use C3 clearance on bearings where a cold start up application my cause the balls to heat up quickly, the heat needs to go somewhere. Some of the heat gets passed through the outer race to the housing and the inner race to the shaft, this causes expansion which closes up the clearance in the bearing. If you did not allow for this clearance the bearing would not have room for expansion and lead to bearing failure.
[2022-06-17T20:01:25] Unknown: Ahh... Interesting. So it's between the inner and outer races to allow expansion of the ball bearings themselves. I always thought it was the OD bearing race to the housing. Is it not that as well?
[2022-06-17T20:07:29] rosheee: ?
[2022-06-17T20:07:30] rosheee: OD?

There are some who believe less rolling resistance because it acts a lubricant ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è. If you put too much and overfill it will definitely create resistance. My rear has a bit because after I notice a tiny bit leaking from the cover screws, I think I added way more than it lost lol. Rear probably has about 8ml if I had to guess. Slight bit of resistance compared to the front. No biggie in my view but may clean it out and go back with a measured 6.5ml so I know for absolute sure what's in there

[2022-06-18T23:58:15] Unknown: Yes. Cc to CV threshold and charge rates are controlled thru the controller. Any power supply or battery can be used as a "charger" and controller regulates cc to cv. I did a super slow charge, 21HR mark. Started at 4a and now is incrementally ramping down to 1a as it approaches 84v full charge
[2022-06-18T23:58:34] Mirono escooters: Ok i love that..

[2022-06-18T23:59:56] Unknown: Yuppers. Amazing feature. Only other controller to have such feature was Adaptto mini and max which is no longer made. Nucs are loosely based off the same idea in general but way more advanced
[2022-06-19T00:01:16] Unknown: So you can for instance... Carry a spare scooter battery (or any battery) in your backpack. When you need a charge, just plug in the battery to your charge plug and your scooter battery will charge from the spare battery

[2022-06-19T20:44:57] Unknown: Ok guys. Got the brakes all set lol. Front and rear have no rub, solid levers, true rotors. Good to go. Little thing I did was when bleeding I took the piston blocks out and used the syringe to push all 4 pistons out about halfway. I lubed them and seals/orings with mineral oil to make sure they have smooth and free action. I think periodically that might be a good idea to keep them moving as freely as possible. The pistons and pads have no springs on the Maguras, so for the pistons to retract they rely on negative vaccum in the lines (when you let go of the lever). So there is basically no "assist" that helps the pistons get pushed back in. Leads me to believe they need to be totally smooth and freely moving to work optimal
[2022-06-19T20:53:51] Mirko Boni: Great explanation! Thanks Adam!
[2022-06-19T20:54:23] Mirko Boni: I bought a 5V throttle!
[2022-06-19T21:03:17] Mirono escooters: Yes lube em!!

[2022-06-19T21:24:12] Unknown: Another trick I found is before you touch the levers when pistons are all the way seated, mount and center the calipers by eye dead center on the rotor. Then when you squeeze the lever, the pistons will automatically end up at the same level. If you squeeze the lever while the caliper is still loose on the mounts the pistons can travel and seat really uneven
[2022-06-19T21:25:43] Unknown: Yup I believe it. After pushing the pistons out and lubing them I noticed the action was actually a lot smoother. You can actually use the syringe to actuate the pistons carefully with the piston blocks removed. You can see if one is stuck or if one is pushing out faster/slower than the others

[2022-06-21T19:06:35] –ö–∏—Ä–∏–ª–ª: Battery ones
[2022-06-21T19:06:41] Her0DasH #311 Johnny Player üá™üá∫: I do similar and than at right time you pull the rabbit out from the hat ,like boomüòÅ
[2022-06-21T19:06:56] Unknown: Yup, main battery leads no bueno
[2022-06-21T19:08:15] Unknown: If resoldering just make super sure you don't flow solder from + to - pads/wires. Those are fairly close and can easily be crossed with too much solder. Maybe is why they dry soldered üòÇ
[2022-06-21T19:11:04] Unknown: Ehh, actually not that close. Solder away lol. And when/if you do... Push the wires down onto the pads while the solder is molten. I use ceramic tweezers for that, won't melt and won't stick. Right now they have the wires sitting above the PCB pads and mostly solder is making the connection. You want the actual wire flattened on the pads. Solder sucks horribly as a conductor. You don't want solder making the connection, rather solder keeping and holding the wire/pad connection
[2022-06-21T19:11:07] rosheee: Question
[2022-06-21T19:11:09] –ö–∏—Ä–∏–ª–ª: It feels like they are just not drowned there, you can just warm up the top with a soldering iron better and add 2 bosses of tin on top
[2022-06-21T19:11:35] rosheee: No solder inside better?
[2022-06-21T19:13:27] Unknown: I always fill completely until solder starts flowing back out of the bullet. Again, you want the wire touching the bullet, not floating in the center. I would trim back the silicone so the wire can push in further, bottom out the wire into the bullet... Then solder fill completely until it is flowing back out

[2022-06-25T03:06:17] Unknown: Yes you need to burn the tips or use a metal wire wheel on a Dremel to take off the lamination on the phase leads... Just where you plan on soldering your new wires to it. If laminations Aren't removed solder with never stick
[2022-06-25T03:07:13] Unknown: Use a torch, metal wire wheel or even sandpaper to take the lamination off the copper wire tips ONLY. FYI, you cannot see the "lamination" it's a very thin layer that costs the copper

[2022-06-28T23:23:24] Artem Bulashev: 1. 3.3v adc bi-directional for programmable controllers 2. 5v mid to max scaled as 0-100% adc for normall controller 3. E-Brake line engager - when you scroll back over 20% seperetae line will close circuits - you connect ebrake here and it will close it to ground. So normal controllers can also use wheel to e-brake. Strength of ebrake is set by original display as before. Than also there is a input for cruise control button, it also has external input wire üôÇüí™

They took certain features of the adaptto controller and improved on them such as charge thru controller function but now the motor coil is used for the stepup rather than a separate external charge coil. Their display was black and white, now it's redesigned and backlit. They were super popular with ebike guys just like Nucular is today

[2022-07-02T16:23:29] Unknown: The factory solder on the phase wires where the wire connects to the copper windings is pretty much impossible to de-solder. It looks like they use copper solder or something that a typical iron will never melt. I cut mine back as close as possible to the factory solder blob and then just cut it off with snips.

[2022-07-04T00:27:52] Unknown: FYI on the adaptto controllers. Again, they are no longer made, probably 4-5 years since they stopped being produced. Nucular took the general idea and built up on it vastly in many aspects. Smaller size, better functionality, higher rated, and way more failsafe. Plus firmware is unrecognizable from adaptto to Nucular. They were groundbreaking and amazing for their time but quickly surpassed in all aspects.
[2022-07-04T00:29:03] Unknown: New Nucs are now implementing encoder motors such as Talaria and QS encoder motors üëå. Even under Russian suppression they are making progress

[2022-07-04T00:56:59] Unknown: Is it nothing I do, it is the controller. Because motor temp sensor is NTC 10k b:3950 and MOSFET internal temp sensor is different beta value at lower temp
[2022-07-04T00:57:52] Unknown: Once up to temp (35-40c) they are both accurate at the same measure. At resting temp the beta values are skewed on the motor probe. MOSFET temp is accurate always
[2022-07-04T00:59:46] Unknown: Externally mounted dual 12Fs on thermal pads. They just stay cool ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è. Vsett 10 motors with 11awg phase wires and (rear) 80/225 85C max at windings and covers barely warm compared to stock Vsett setup motors on same ride and terrain (compared cover temps to stock Vsett of a friend after the same ride) ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è. I don't what else you want me to say.
[2022-07-04T01:11:49] Unknown: 12Fs externally mounted using dual layers of thermal pads and plexiglass plate between them. Rear controller is hottest and goes 10-15C above ambient at most with 80a batt/225a phase on rear. Front is slightly less and stay very close to ambient always

[2022-07-04T01:17:47] Unknown: Plexiglass is for rigidity and mounting purposes, nothing to do with thermal anything
[2022-07-04T01:19:35] Unknown: I just cut plexiglass plates and mounted the controllers to them because the controllers are mounted to an odd shaped surface. Then I put thermal pads on each side of that plexiglass plate. I really did that to reduce vibrations and shock to the controllers, had nothing to do with thermal concerns. May have inadvertently created a decent cooling solution in the process
[2022-07-04T01:20:35] Mirono escooters: No one uses plexi for cooling, cmon

It is obtained from rapeseed oil and is harmless to humans and the environment. The high boiling point makes it particularly suitable for use in biking. The Heinzelmann Bleedkit from Trickstuff is ideal for changing the brake fluid and also bleeding.
[2022-07-07T00:47:06] rosheee: - pure plant oil - toxin class free, low evaporation, not hazardous to water - completely biodegradable - boiling point is 420¬∞ C - maximum compressive strength - extremely thin

[2022-07-08T12:12:53] √óÔº°ÔºØÔº≤ÔºµÔº≥√ó: can I please have the instructions
[2022-07-08T12:13:05] Izuna ÁîüÊ¥ª: one sec
[2022-07-08T12:13:12] √óÔº°ÔºØÔº≤ÔºµÔº≥√ó: Thanks
[2022-07-08T12:13:18] √óÔº°ÔºØÔº≤ÔºµÔº≥√ó: Very much
[2022-07-08T12:13:27] Izuna ÁîüÊ¥ª: (VESC firmware update) 1. Open the VESC tool in the 7z 2. Connect to VESC (might show errors about motor config deserialization etc ignore it) 3. Go to Firmware 4. Click on Bootloader -> select "generic" or something -> press the button with the downwards showing arrow 5. Wait a few seconds and reconnect (it will restart probably) 6. Go to Custom File -> Select "VESC_default.bin" file from "75_100_V2_no_limits" folder -> press the button with the downwards showing arrow 5. Wait a few seconds and reconnect (it will restart probably) 7. Now you can start using the VESC (Basic VESC usage) 1. Connect 2. Press "Setup Motors FOC" and follow the setup guide 3. Choose direction and let it spin around 4. See realtime data with "RT" button on the right side bar and control motor with arrow keys with arrowkeys button on the right side bar

[2022-07-11T11:07:16] rosheee: high kv motors need higher frequency
[2022-07-11T11:07:43] rosheee: A final point here would be to look at the R-L characteristics of your motor. Your motor windings have a time constant 12 (Just divide motor winding inductance by motor resistance) so at a certain switching frequency (about (10x time constant)^-1) it doesn‚Äôt much matter if you switch any faster because the motor winding current can‚Äôt physically change any quicker.

[2022-07-17T02:44:45] Jan: Short on the motorcable?
[2022-07-17T02:58:14] Unknown: Phase is shorting to the mover cover or axle. Shouldn't be the actual windings since they're laminated and even if they were touching the cover on the inside, it shouldn't short. Your solder joint inside might be touching or you have a cut in the wire that is shorting to the axle. Does the axle also have continuity?
[2022-07-17T03:20:19] rosheee: Yup
[2022-07-17T04:14:55] Unknown: Did you re-wire that motor with bigger phase wires?
[2022-07-17T04:18:37] Unknown: That's why I didn't try n squeeze in huge phase wires myself, didn't want to chance them getting sliced at the axle opening over time. 11awg X 3 (Higo L1019 cable) has been working perfectly on some pretty high settings. 80/225 on the rear and phase wires are completely fine. Never heat up to anywhere near concerning. 50mm magnet Vsett motor will only benefit so much from huge phase wires, diminishing returns so to speak

[2022-07-17T23:19:24] Her0DasH #311 Johnny Player üá™üá∫: Could you explain a bit
[2022-07-17T23:22:28] Her0DasH #311 Johnny Player üá™üá∫: So its clear you spin there and back My question would be how sensitive is it to spin, not sure how to describe Also if you let it go what happens ,returns to neutral or keeps position?
[2022-07-17T23:31:14] Unknown: I'm assuming it returns to zero as it has a button for cruise controll already. I asked about the throw or sensitivity as stock is ridiculously jerky
[2022-07-17T23:33:29] Her0DasH #311 Johnny Player üá™üá∫: Well lets see ,but all is kinda needed information
[2022-07-18T00:10:40] Artem Bulashev: Yes it would return to 0 position. On VESC forward scroll is acceleration, back backwards is variable regen brake. On normal controller forward is same but on dedicated wire (that wire output ignores scrolling back, because normal controllers can‚Äôt process it). Backward scroll can be blocked by included screw, so you won‚Äôt be able to scroll back. Or you can connect E-brake wire and have e-brake engage at -20% backward scroll on any normal controller üòé this way you can utilize bidirectional operation even on normal controller ‚ù§Ô∏è
[2022-07-18T00:12:38] Artem Bulashev: Lastly there is cruise button, tap it and throttle output will be held üëç you can release wheel. If you move wheel again, throttle hold will be immediately disabled. - that button actually has input cable, which allows you to use it for any other external application that needs momentary switch , like horn for example
[2022-07-18T00:16:12] D J: I'm happy...I'll get with CNC ü§©
[2022-07-18T00:56:40] Artem Bulashev: It is cnc if you get now yeah, as of tomorrow you will be able to select what wheel you want (now it is aluminum only)
[2022-07-18T01:17:03] rosheee: Fastride doesnt reply anymore lol
[2022-07-18T01:17:12] rosheee: Scam company lol
[2022-07-18T01:54:37] Unknown: That's really smart design man. Works for everyone. That's what a lot of companies miss in this industry. Single faceted devices that are only friendly to their system. A universal bi-directional throttle really is a beautiful thing ‚ù§Ô∏è

[2022-07-29T15:44:53] Jan: Be aware that the temperatures are wrong. This is due to an effect called black body radiation emissivity. The epsilon coefficient varies with different materials and surface grades and can throw your measurement off by a lot that it is no longer valid.
[2022-07-29T15:45:35] Jan: Totally viable solution if you do it right
[2022-07-29T15:46:38] Jan: This is just an example table. Do not measure it like this if you did not coat the whole surface in the same material https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emissivity https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_body#:~:text=Real%20materials%20emit%20energy%20at,has%20an%20emissivity%20%CE%B5%20%3D%201.

[2022-08-04T23:19:58] Ofek üê•: Thermal cutoff at 75¬∞C I Have to cool them fets faster üôàüòÑ (Flipsky 75100 with custom heatsink)
[2022-08-04T23:24:58] Jan: At what power and for how long?

[2022-08-04T23:25:45] Ofek üê•: I will add the log tomorrow 5.5kw peak
[2022-08-04T23:27:14] Ofek üê•: <photos/photo_5538@04-08-2022_23-27-14.jpg>
[2022-08-04T23:27:40] Jan: Picture of cooling solution?
[2022-08-05T00:58:34] sombre_enfant: Cooling ?
[2022-08-05T05:02:35] Izuna ÁîüÊ¥ª: That is so awesome. üòÑ I would recommend to replace the MOSFETs, if you are using the stock Flipsky 75100 (not the Alu PCB one, this one already has good ones). With the stock MOSFETs, I feel like you can have the best cooling solution, but the MOSFETs will still heat up enough itself because the heat won't dissipate fast enough to the heatsink. (does that make sense?) At least from my testing I noticed with my huge copper heatsink, they will stay much cooler, but still heat up very quickly and strong. As soon as I decrease power/cut power they are almost instantaneous to normal temperature. Which is very good, so my heatsink does work, but not enough thermal conductivity at the MOSFETs to keep them cool at full power. I have Kaptontape with Thermal Paste, maybe Thermal Pads would be better or put heatsink also above MOSFETs for even more surface area? üòÖ I have a modified Flipsky 75100 with HUASHUO HSP0076A (100V 308A 429W 1.8mŒ©) MOSFETs, which I am going to try soon with my copper heatsink and then I'll see how it performs. I already used it with the stock aluminium heatsink, but had a lil accident with my BMS which killed the ESC, so had to repair it first. üòÖ
[2022-08-05T07:20:28] Ofek üê•: Thanks bro!! When I stop accelerating the heatsink pull the heat from the mosfets. I tried cheap thermal pads but settled on thermal paste + kapton until I'll get higher quality thermal pads üòÖ
[2022-08-05T08:59:08] Jan: Its not really about materials, if your cooling concept is wrong, it will not compensate that much with better materials
[2022-08-05T09:00:38] Jan: Good advice: Make thermal energy transfer distances as short as possible.

[2022-08-05T21:27:33] Jan: Rion Tronic 250: "the TDP is dynamic and dependent on the motor current. The factors are the MOSFET Rds(on) resistance and the motor current at that time. The heat given off by each mosfet are (I^2)*R losses. Rds(on) for these MOSFETs is 2.1mOhm. So for example, heat dissipated for each mosfet at 150A motor current is 150*150*0.0021 = 47.25W. This means that 283.5W total is being dissipated when accounting for all 6 mosfets. However, the average motor current is much less when looking at these logs."
[2022-08-05T21:28:06] Jan: (90A logs)

[2022-08-05T23:07:51] Mirono escooters: Beryllium oxide, also known as beryllia, is an inorganic compound with the formula BeO. This colourless solid is a notable electrical insulator with a higher thermal conductivity than any other non-metal except diamond, and exceeds that of most metals. As an amorphous solid, beryllium oxide is white.

[2022-08-15T21:32:19] Mirono escooters: Eh hard and water
[2022-08-15T21:32:51] Jan: Water is a medium of transport and acts also like a thermal mass (which is not always wanted). I dont think there is a TDP high enough in the scooter area that it is worth to use as heat transport. The disadvantages are too big for it to be worth.
[2022-08-15T21:33:49] Jan: What you want is heat exchange and the only thing you got is air surrounding your scooter. With enough speed you get quite some convection, that means the more exchange surface you have, the more heat you can dissipate
[2022-08-15T21:36:20] Jan: What the problem is, how can you reach the most heat exchange surface in the shortest amount of time from the mosfet surface. The answer is high thermal conductivity of materials and short distances
